title: Survey on Governance of User-generated Content in Web Communities

author: Felix Schwagereit, Institute for Web Science and Technologies (WeST), University of Koblenz-Landau

segmentation: I'm from the West Institute, here in Corpus.
From this Institute in comments.
Content and I'm presenting you a survey on governance of user generated content in web.
Communities communities are like guards, so you, as a community owner can provide the infrastructure of the soil and it can see something out.
But then you have to wait for the user generated content to grow.
Of course you can do something more.
You can water some parts, or you can read out some other parts you don't want to have.
And that is governance.

So governance for us is steering and coordinating the action of Community members with the goal of a successful and flourishing community with high quality, user generated content and active community members.
So what is the motivation for work?
As we all know there's different types of web communities and different types of user generated content.
The question is, what are the most successful means of governance for this user?
Generated content in the web communities?
And we try to shed some light on it by analyzing successful platforms and compare their means of governance.
So what are the means of governance for us?
There are in general two different types, so at first you could, as a community owner with some direct interventions in the community.
Of course you have the power you you own the infrastructure.
You can monitor whatever is going on there.
You can monitor the content and you can monitor the users and you can for example delete some content if you don't want it.
Or you can expel some some members of the communities.
But that's not the most important and not.
The most interesting means of governance.
That's why we have looked at something else.
That is the means of governance that is provided functionality within the Community platform and that allows the users the Community members to support governance themselves, self governance.
Important for us is user generated content and of course the community member.
What can the community member do with it generated content at first?
Of course this selects some content and drinks it and sees what content is interesting and after that it consumes the content and assess the content.
And if we're lucky provides some rating or some information about the content.
Also, the user can of course in some platforms, like Wikipedia modified content, this is only possible if the user has given have been given as some additional privileges like in Wikipedia.
There are very complex role models where regulars moderators and so on.
But now we want to dive a little bit more in deeper into the assessment of user generated content by the community members.
So it first community members can do some rating.
The most simple one like or a little bit more complex like and dislike or in other shapes it's called was this helpful.
There are many, there are many shapes of the same thing.
Of course, we also have more complex ratings, like the device Star rating and so on for one or for many categories.
User can also provide text reviews or bookmark or provide abuse reports for user generated content.
And after this this information can be also used for selection and ranking.
You can do a selection ranking by space of ratings on times views the number of views.
For example figure this is very popular in the number of replies.
You can hide low quality content from the user or you can use selection based off score.
This is independent from the content itself.
This is only based on ratings or reviews.
Of course it is also the possibility to rank or select content based on the topic or or keywords.
So what was the method of our survey?
So we selected over 250 most prominent website with community functionality according to Alexa patron and then we cluster the website in four groups according to their purpose.

These groups are social media, editorial use, social networking and social reviewing with this clustering, because otherwise we observed that there was too much weight in the social media type of Community platform and we want to and wanted to have a very broadview on.
On this on this side with with a great variety of means of governance, social media is it could imagine.
This is the typical ones you expect for user generated content, YouTube, Flickr, etc.
Where the users providing some content and other users are viewing it, reveling iterating it.
Editorial News is a little bit different, so there are the main focal accompany.
Item is not provided by the users itself, but by the site, but there's also user generated content because there were comments and discussions.
We have to be governed.
The third category is social networking.
Also there the user generated content is not in the in the focal point, but there's also user generated content like in Facebook for example the wall posts.
Although there is the focus lies on the on the explicit social connections there.
And the 4th category is social regular and it's very very heterogeneous category cause they are the focal items are could be physical ones, for example that are not provided by the platform itself.
So something that you can buy at Amazon or eBay or a movie Internet movie database.
And what we've done is we selected the top five websites of each of this group and analyze them with one exception for the social media.
We also included answers.com to have at least one question answer in part from there.
So I cannot show you show you the the whole of the results in eight minutes, but I've selected for key results to tell you so keep it on number one is abuse.
Reports are apparently a successful means of governance.
Out of 21 we have observed the 16 occurrences.
Can say OK, it's no use tricks that use reportes because you can.
The only thing you can do with it is to filter out unwanted content.
And do you still need some stuff, some paid stuff?
Who review the abuse report?
So it's also a little bit expensive, but it's very efficient as we as we could see and observe in previous work which was submitted last years to adapt against last year's websites conference.
So the key result #2 is that simple ratings are dominant.
But this seems to be a battle between the most simple ones like and like and dislike, so we have 9 occurrences of life and seven occurrences of like and dislike with no real.
We cannot explain this.
Of course there are some ups and downs for each of them.
There's a tradeoff between simplicity and improved ranking ability be cause.

For example, with the with the lights you cannot filter out the really bad content items because we don't know if it's is it neutral, so nobody cares and nobody wants to a click like or is it really bad?
Nobody has the option of saying it is like.
But there's no, there's no pattern in it.
Chivas Alchemistry is that creation Time is the most implemented rating criteria, so you could say OK, creation time.
What does this do to do with governments?
Even if it's 18 times in our survey, much more than than other scores or ranking based on ratings, we could also see this as a means of governance.
Becausw important content is renewed, so it's it's also kind of rating and unimportant content.
Can be forgotten if it's not.
If it's not renewed or if it's not replied to secure them before content modification and user roles are rarely implemented.
We have only two occurrences of these.
This is a little bit surprising 'cause this seems to be very efficient and very nice means of government, so you can.
You can give privileges to users so that so they can govern the content themselves, but it seems that is for many applications.
It's much to comply.
So what's the conclusion of our work?
There?
Similar means of governance in each bedroom type.
We can identify some best practices, for example abuse reports, which platform type.
But the governance means very in detail very much.
For example, the rating schemes and the finding still finding the right governance means is an art today and there was no common means of governance through all the platforms.
So what is needed for better governance?
We need more quantitative analysis.

A bit bigger, bigger survey and more specific survey on specific community types and specific content types, and we need governance model to recommend specific governance means for specific applications.
Thank you much.
